person_602.name: Plutarch
person_602.description: Greek writer most famous for his parallel lives of Greek and Roman statesmen and military leaders.

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_604.name: SilenusCalatinus
person_604.description: Sicilian Greek historian of Magna Graecia who wrote a history in Greek of Hannibal's campaign in Italy from 218 to 204 BC. His work is known only from fragments and borrowings by other authors.

person_601.name: Daimachus
person_601.description: Probably: Daimachus, Greek diplomat and writer.

person_756.name: Lysander
person_756.description: A Spartan military and political leader. He destroyed the Athenian fleet at the Battle of Aegospotami in 405 BCE, forcing Athens to capitulate and bringing the Peloponnesian War to an end.

person_757.name: PierreGassendi
person_757.description: French philosopher, Catholic priest, astronomer and mathematician who published the first data on the transit of Mercury in 1631.

person_764.name: EdwardTopham
person_764.description: English journalist and playwright, who publicized the Wold Cottage meteorite that fell on his property.

person_767.name: JamesSowerby
person_767.description: English naturalist and illustrator, a member of the Geological and Linnean  Societies. FRSL.

person_203.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
person_203.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

person_634.name: Jacques Louis deBournon
person_634.description: French born mineralogist who lived and worked in London. An Annual Subscribed to the Royal Institution, he was founder member of the Geological Society. FRSL.

person_553.name: LukeHoward
person_553.description: Quaker who published a nomenclature for clouds and meteorology. Part of partnership Allen and Howard, supplier of chemicals, pharmaceutics and apparatus. FRSL.

person_244.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
person_244.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

person_050.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
person_050.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_772.name: David BailieWarden
person_772.description: Republican insurgent in the Irish Rebellion of 1798 and, in later exile, a United States consul in Paris.

person_768.name: JosephIzarn
person_768.description: Author of Lithologie Atmospherique (1803) and inspector of French universities.

person_505.name: EdmondHalley
person_505.description: Astronomer and natural philosopher, who, using Newtonian mechanics, predicted the return of what became the eponymous comet. FRSL.

person_130.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
person_130.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

person_051.name: JohnPringle
person_051.description: Physician who served as President of the Royal Society of London, 1772-1778. Created a baronet. FRSL.

person_769.name: ErnstChladni
person_769.description: German physicist and musician who undertook pioneering work in the study of meteorites and invented Chladni plates.

person_455.name: BenjaminSilliman
person_455.description: American chemist and science educator, professor at Yale College. Founded the American Journal of Science. Met Davy when he visited London in 1805.

person_691.name: Jahangir I
person_691.description: Nur-ud-Din Muhammad Salim, known by his imperial name Jahangir ('Conqueror of the World'), was the fourth Mughal emperor, who ruled from 1605 until death.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_867.name: Thrace
place_867.description: Thrace is a geographical and historical region in Southeast Europe. Bounded by the Balkan Mountains to the north, the Aegean Sea to the south, and the Black Sea to the east, it comprises present-day southeastern Bulgaria, northeastern Greece, and the European part of Turkey, roughly the Roman Province of Thrace.

place_868.name: Gos
place_868.description: Aegospotami is the ancient Greek name for a small river issuing into the Hellespont northeast of Sestos. According to Pliny and Aristotle, a meteor landed here in 467 BC after reports of a comet.

place_905.name: Mount Vaisi
place_905.description: A mountain in the Alpes-Maritimes which was the site of a meteor fall in 1637. The coordinates given are approximate.

place_1087.name: Provence
place_1087.description: Provence is a region in southeastern France which borders the Mediterranean Sea and Italy.

place_622.name: Verona
place_622.description: Verona is a city located on the Adige River in the north of Italy.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_871.name: Maine (France)
place_871.description: Maine is one of the traditional provinces of France. It corresponds to the former County of Maine, whose capital was also the city of Le Mans.

place_1191.name: Mediterranean Sea
place_1191.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

place_287.name: Yorkshire
place_287.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

place_880.name: Varanasi
place_880.description: a city in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh dating to the 11th century B.C. now known as Varanasi

place_356.name: Lyon
place_356.description: Lyon is the third-largest city in France. It is located at the confluence of the Rivers Rhône and Saône, to the north-west of the French Alps.

place_741.name: Siena
place_741.description: A city in Tuscany, and the capital of the Province of Siena.

place_886.name: Mauerkirchen
place_886.description: a municipality in the district of Braunau am Inn in the Austrian state of Upper Austria.

place_887.name: Glasgow
place_887.description: Glasgow is a port city on the River Clyde in Scotland's western Lowlands.

place_888.name: L'Aigle
place_888.description: L'Aigle is a commune in the Orne department in Normandy in northwestern France.

place_878.name: United States
place_878.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

place_897.name: France
place_897.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

place_892.name: Cape of Good Hope
place_892.description: The Cape of Good Hope is a rocky headland on the Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula in South Africa.

place_990.name: Siberia
place_990.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges

place_893.name: Punjab, India
place_893.description: Punjab, a state bordering Pakistan, is the heart of India’s Sikh community.

otherwork_194.name: Des Pierres Tombées du Ciel: Lithologie Atmosphérique Présentant la Marche Et l'État Actuel de la Science sur le Phénomène des Pierres de Foudre, ... Tombées du Ciel, Etc
otherwork_194.author: Joseph Izarn

otherwork_195.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_195.author: John Pringle
